metadata.title: Quasi-QSAR for predicting the cell viability of human lung and skin cells exposed to different metal oxide nanomaterials

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Chemosphere
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate/chemosphere
Quasi-QSAR for predicting the cell viability of human lung and skin cells exposed to different metal oxide nanomaterials
Jang-Sik Choi a, 1, Tung X. Trinh b, Tae-Hyun Yoon b, Jongwoon Kim c, *, Hyung-Gi Byun a, **
a Division of Electronics, Information and Communication Engineering, Kangwon National University (Samcheok), Kangwon-do, 25913, Republic of Korea b Department of Chemistry, College of Natural Sciences, Hanyang University, Seoul, 04763, Republic of Korea c Environmental Safety Group, Korea Institute of Science and Technology (KIST) Europe, Campus E 7.1, Saarbrueck-en, Germany
h i g h l i g h t s
A Quasi-QSAR for cell viability (%) of BEAS-2B and HaCaT cells exposed to metal oxide nanomaterials was developed. Cell viability was estimated using quasi-SMILES for physicochemical properties and experimental conditions. The quasi-SMILES codes were generated by hierarchical cluster analysis (HCA). The statistical quality of quasi-QSAR was good.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 25 July 2018 Received in revised form 21 October 2018 Accepted 2 November 2018 Available online 3 November 2018
Handling Editor: Tamara S. Galloway
Keywords: metal oxide nanomaterial BEAS-2B HaCaT Cell viability Quasi-QSAR Quasi-SMILES
* Corresponding author. Present address: Chemical Research Institute of Chemical Technology (KRICT), Daejeon, 34114, Republic of Korea. ** Corresponding author.
E-mail addresses: with.jwkim@gmail.com (J. (H.-G. Byun).
1 Current address: Center for Next Generation Cyt Seoul, 04763, Republic of Korea.
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.chemosphere.2018.11.014 0045-6535/© 2018 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
A quasi-QSAR model was developed to predict the cell viability of human lung (BEAS-2B) and skin (HaCaT) cells exposed to 21 types of metal oxide nanomaterials. A wide range of toxicity datasets obtained from the S2NANO (www.s2nano.org) database was used. The data of descriptors representing the physicochemical properties and experimental conditions were coded to quasi-SMILES. In particular, hierarchical cluster analysis (HCA) and min-max normalization method were respectively used in assigning alphanumeric codes for numerical descriptors (e.g., core size, hydrodynamic size, surface charge, and dose) and then quasi-QSAR model performances for both methods were compared. The quasi-QSAR models were developed using CORAL software (www.insilico.eu/coral). Quasi-QSAR model built using quasi-SMILES generated by means of HCA showed better performance than the min-max normalization method. The model showed satisfactory statistical results (R2adj for the training dataset: 0.71e0.73; R2adj for the calibration dataset: 0.74e0.82; and R 2 adj for the validation dataset: 0.70e0.76).
© 2018 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Many nanomaterials are newly engineered and employed in an extensive variety of commercial products such as electronic components, cosmetics, food, and medicine. With the increasing utilization of nanomaterials, the interest in the hazard of nanomaterials
Safety Research Center, Korea 141 Gajeong-ro, Yuseong-gu,
Kim), byun@kangwon.ac.kr
ometry, Hanyang University,
to human health and the environment has steadily increased. The toxicity of nanomaterials has been evaluated by conducting in vivo, in vitro, and in silico studies (Frohlich and Salar-Behzadi, 2014). In particular, in silico studies have been conducted to complement in vitro and in vivo toxicity tests to potentiallyminimize the need for animal testing, reduce the cost and time of toxicity tests, and improve toxicity prediction and safety assessment (Raies and Bajic, 2016).
Quantitative structureeactivity relationships (QSARs), as in silico model, has been developed to predict biological activities, including the toxicity of various substances (Randi c, 1991), mainly based on molecular structure (McNaught and Wilkinson, 1997), simplified molecular input line entry systems (SMILES) (Weininger, 1988), and international chemical identifiers (InChI) (Heller et al.,
2013). When it comes to nanomaterials, such classic QSAR approaches have shown many limitations in predicting the toxicity of different nanomaterials. A main reason for the limitations is caused by the lack of standardised databases on their structures together with physicochemical and biomedical endpoints (Oksel et al., 2015). In addition, as the toxic effects of nanomaterials vary according to their physicochemical properties and the same type of nanomaterials exhibit diverse toxic effects to different biochemical conditions (e.g., cell line, cell species, etc.) (Gatoo et al., 2014; Podila and Brown, 2013; Zhao et al., 2012), it makes the development of classic QSAR difficult.
To overcome the limitations of classic QSAR on nanomaterials, QSAR based quasi-SMILES (quasi-QSAR) were proposed by Toropova and Toropov (A Toropov et al., 2015; Bragazzi et al., 2016; Manganelli et al., 2016a; Manganelli et al., 2016b; P Toropova and A Toropov, 2015; Toropov et al., 2013b, 2015, 2016; Toropov and Toropova, 2014, 2015b; Toropova and Toropov, 2013, 2017; Toropova et al., 2014, 2015a, 2015b, 2015c, 2016a, 2016b, 2017). In the quasi-QSAR model development process, the physicochemical property of nanomaterials and biochemical conditions are represented by quasi-SMILES. Quasi-SMILES is representation of eclectic data related to an endpoint, where eclectic data is all conditions (controlled or observed) that have influence over the experiment results (Bragazzi et al., 2016). The quasi-SMILES provides a suitable framework for developing predictive models for nanomaterials since one can integrate, within a simple syntactic sequence (i.e., character string), all of the available eclectic data that impacts the physicochemical and/or biochemical behavior of nanomaterials (Toropov et al., 2015).
In quasi-QSAR models, data of descriptors were coded by assigning a number between 0 and 9 in a single character. For numerical descriptors such as physicochemical properties, theminmax normalizationmethod was used (Toropova and Toropov, 2013; Toropova et al., 2014). Data for each numerical descriptor was normalized by min-max normalization method and then the interval [0, 1] of the normalized data was divided into equal-sized 10 subintervals. The number codes from 0 to 9 were assigned to each subinterval, as listed in Table S1. Finally, codes for the numerical descriptors were assigned by considering their normalized values and the 10 subintervals. For example, if normalized data of engineered size is 0.05 and a character ‘A’ is used to define the descriptor, the code becomes ‘A0’.
This code assignment method using min-max normalization causes a problem that all codes are not effectively assigned. This method always assigns the 10 number codes to the equal-sized 10 subintervals regardless of data distribution. In case that data is unevenly distributed, some number codes are assigned to related subintervals by this method even though data does not exist within the subintervals. Therefore, after the code assignment by min-max normalization, some codes are not utilized in developing the quasiQSARmodel. The performance of the quasi-QSARmode depends on the number of codes which represent related subintervals of continuous data. The sensitivity of the quasi-QSARmodel decreases as the number of codes used in the development of the quasi-QSAR model decreases. Consequently, the sensitivity decrease degrades the performance of the quasi-QSAR model.
To solve the problem raised by min-max normalization method for the quasi-QSAR, we proposed a new quasi-SMILES code assignment method based on hierarchical cluster analysis (HCA) in our previous study (Trinh et al., 2018a). This method assigns all possible codes to n groups divided based on the similarity between data of numerical descriptor. In the study, codes for data of numerical descriptors such as diameter, length, surface area, and dose were assigned by HCA, and then quasi-QSAR models for predicting
the cytotoxicity of 20 different types of multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) to human lung cells were developed. The developedmodels provided satisfactory statistical results (R2 for internal validation data sets: 0.60e0.80; R2pred for external validation data sets: 0.81e0.88).
The objectives of this studywere to develop a quasi-QSARmodel to predict the cell viability (%) of human bronchial epithelial cells (BEAS-2B) and human keratinocyte cells (HaCaT) exposed to 21 metal oxide nanomaterials, and validate the quasi-SMILES code assignment method based on HCA.

sections.heading: 2.1. Data
sections.text:
Safe and sustainable nanotechnology (S2NANO) community, a research group in the Republic of Korea, built an S2NANO database including various toxicity datasets related to nanomaterials obtained from different sources, such as experimental-, article-, and report-based sources.
The quality of collected toxicity data was assessed by physicochemical (PChem) scoring approach proposed by the S2NANO research group (Ha et al., 2018; Trinh et al., 2018b). The PChem scoring approach evaluates the data quality on physicochemical properties (core size, hydrodynamic size, surface charge, and surface area) with consideration for the data source (experiment, manufacture, and article) and measurement method (the characterization methods for physicochemical properties: e.g., TEM, DLS, BET, etc). If data were generated by widely recognized and acknowledged techniques such as TEM, DLS, and BET, the data is given higher score.
High-PChem score ensures the reproducibility and reliability of data. As good quality input always results in the accurate prediction of properties, high quality data thoroughly evaluated by PChem scoring approach was used in this paper.
From the S2NANO database, BEAS-2B and HaCaT cells were chosen in this study because they are widely used as models relevant for nanomaterial toxicity evaluations (Gibbs, 2009). The cell viability data for BEAS-2B and HaCaT, which was extracted from the S2NANO database, was comprised of 336 rows and 8 columns (nanomaterial type, core size, hydrodynamic size, surface charge, assay method, cell line, dose, and cell viability). The cell viability data originated from 6 research articles (Akhtar et al., 2012; Comfort et al., 2014; Gajewicz et al., 2015; Xiong et al., 2013; Yang et al., 2010; Zhang et al., 2012) about the cytotoxicity of metal oxide nanomaterials. A summary of the dataset is presented in Table 1.
BEAS-2B and HaCaT cells were exposed to 21 different metal oxide nanomaterials with various physicochemical properties influenced by the core size, hydrodynamic size, and surface charge. The exposure time of all datasets was 24 h. The concentration of nanomaterials ranged from 0 to 1500 ppm. Six different toxicity assay methods were used to measure the BEAS-2B and HaCaT cell viability, with the results expressed as a percentage in comparison with the control samples. Cell viability was used as an endpoint and seven parameters (nanomaterial type, core size, hydrodynamic size, surface charge, toxic assay method, cell line, and dose) were used to build up a quasi-QSAR model. Three random splits into the visible training set (in fact, this is structured into two sets: 60% training set and 20% calibration set) and the 20% invisible validation set was examined.

sections.heading: 2.2. Quasi-SMILES
sections.text:
Quasi-SMILES is a string representing physicochemical features
Table 1 Nanomaterial cell viability data.

10.0 e193.0 208.3e339.5 46.1e32.2 ATP, LDH, MTS BEAS2B 0.4 e200.0 13.1 e100.0 180 Zhang et al. (2012)
24983896 15 NPs Al2O3, Bi2O3, Cr2O3, Fe2O3, In2O3, La2O3, Mn2O3, NiO,
Sb2O3, SnO2, TiO2, WO3, Y2O3, ZnO, ZrO2
20.0 e150 179.6e2029.0 20.2e5.7 CytoToxGlo HaCaT 0 e1500.0 0e106.0 132 Gajewicz et al. (2015)
20180970 SiO2 15.0 13.0 14.4 CCK-8 HaCaT 0e80.0 2.6 e100.0 8 Yang et al. (2010)
25260222 Ag 53.3 155.3 11.9 MTS HaCaT 0e100.0 38.0 e102.0 7 Comfort et al. (2014) 22983807 TiO2 10.0 1457.0 11.0 MTS BEAS2B 0e300.0 84.5 e100.0 5 Xiong et al. (2013) 22393286 ZnO 21.34 127.0 33.0 MTT BEAS2B 0e15.0 33.4 e100.0 4 Akhtar et al. (2012)
and/or biochemical conditions as an alternative to traditional SMILES. Quasi-SMILES used in this study is made of seven components: four codes for physicochemical properties and dose, and three codes for nanomaterial type, toxic assaymethod, and cell line. A combination of alphabet and number (i.e., A0, A1,…) was used to build up the quasi-SMILES. Alphabet from ‘A’ to ‘E’ was used to define the core size, hydrodynamic size, surface charge, toxic assay method, and dose. The number from 0 to 9was used to represent 10 subranges divided by HCA or min-max normalization. In addition, the number was used to distinguish toxic assay methods together with alphabet ‘D’.
For nanomaterial, separator (dot, ‘.’) was used between chemical elements to represent different kinds of nanomaterial type according to rule already defined in previously published article (Toropova et al., 2015a). The codes for nanomaterial type are listed in Table 2.
The plus and minus signs were used to represent BEAS-2B and HeCaT cell lines, respectively. The codes for toxic assay method and cell line are listed in Table 3. For the numerical descriptors such as core size, hydrodynamic size, surface charge, and dose, min-max normalization and HCA approach were respectively used to assign codes.
For building codes for the numerical values of descriptors, the
following normalization equation (1) was first used in previously published papers (Toropova and Toropov, 2013; Toropova et al., 2014).
NormðXkÞ ¼ minXk þ Xk
minXk þmaxXk (1)
This normalization method cannot be applied to a descriptor having negative values. Therefore, equation (2) was used for normalization and then the categorical code was assigned according to the normalized value (Tables S1 and S2).
NormðXkÞ ¼ Xk minXk
maxXk minXk (2)
After code assignment by min-max normalization, it was confirmed that codes such as A5, A6, A8, B4, B5, B8, C2, C7, E4, E7, and E8 were not used. To utilize all possible codes and overcome this limitation of min-max normalization, the quasi-SMILES code assignment method based on HCA was used. HCA is a cluster analysis method in data mining used to establish a hierarchy of clusters. The result can be visualised using heat maps and dendrograms. HCA attempts to group data objects with similar features into the cluster. The n data objects are grouped into n separate clusters with HCA (Zhang et al., 2017).
The unique values of each descriptor were grouped into 10 subranges divided by HCA as shown in Fig. S1 and then codes for core size, hydrodynamic size, surface charge, and dose were assigned as listed in Table 4.
The assigned codes were joined into a string considered as quasi-SMILES. For examples, if BEAS-2B cell (‘þ’) is exposed to 10 mg/mL Ag nanomaterial (Ag.) with core size 15 nm (‘A0’), hydrodynamic size 20 nm (‘B0’), and surface charge 42 mV (‘C0’) and ATP assay (‘D0’) is used to measure cell viability, quasi-SMILES becomes “Ag.A0B0C0D0þE0”. The quasi-SMILES combined with cell viability (endpoint) is used to build up the quasi-QSAR model.
Table 4 Code for physicochemical properties and doses based on HCA.
Core Size (nm) Code Hydrodynamic Size (nm) Code Surface Charge (mV) Code Dose (ug/mL) Code

sections.heading: 2.3. Quasi-QSAR modelling
sections.text:
The quasi-SMILES-based QSAR model can be represented by the following equation:
Cell viabilityð%Þ ¼ C0þ C1*DCW T ;NEpoch
(3)
Where C0 and C1 are the intercept and slope. Correlation weight of the descriptor (DCW) is calculated using the following equation:
DCW T ;NEpoch
¼ X CWðCkÞ (4)
Where Ck corresponds to the codes extracted from the quasiSMILES representation, and CW(Ck) are the correlation weights of various Ck, calculated via a Monte Carlo optimisation. Threshold (T) and the number of epochs (NEpoch) are parameters of the optimisation that provide the preferred statistical quality required for the calibration set. Having the numerical data on CW(Ck) one can calculate DCW(T, NEpoch) for all quasi-SMILES (for more detailed information see references (Toropov and Toropova, 2014; Toropova and Toropov, 2013; Toropova et al., 2015a)).
To develop quasi-QSAR models, CORAL software (http://www. insilico.eu/coral) was used in this study. Among the three random splits (e.g., training, calibration, and validation sets) described in Section Data, the training and calibration sets were used for the model development. The calibration set was employed to avoid the overtraining of quasi-QSAR models. The validation of the quasiQSAR models was conducted with the validation set.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
Model performance for two code assignmentmethods (HCA and min-max normalization method) was compared. The same splits were used to compare model performance under the same conditions.
The following three quasi-QSAR models were built with quasiSMILES based on HCA: (CV: cell viability)
Split 1:

CVð%Þ ¼ 163:30ð±0:70Þ þ 21:13ð±0:06Þ*DCWð5;15Þ (5) Split 2:
CVð%Þ ¼ 260:31ð±1:01Þ þ 28:42ð±0:09Þ*DCWð1;15Þ (6) Split 3:
CVð%Þ ¼ 193:79ð±0:83Þ þ 21:89ð±0:07Þ*DCWð5;17Þ (7) Table 5 contains the statistical characteristics of these models. In the table, n is the number of rows in a training set, calibration set, or validation set. R2adj is the adjusted R 2 (coefficient of multiple determination). Q2 is the leave-one-out cross-validated correlation coefficient. Mean absolute error (MAE) is a measure of difference between the observed response values and predicted values. The parameter c R2p ensures that the developed models are not obtained by chance (Y-randomisation test) (Ojha and Roy, 2011). The following three quasi-QSAR models were built with quasiSMILES based on min-max normalization. Split 1:
CVð%Þ ¼ 127:45ð±0:67Þ þ 15:92ð±0:05Þ*DCWð5;21Þ (8) Split 2:
CVð%Þ ¼ 81:91ð±0:57Þ þ 12:88ð±0:05Þ*DCWð4;38Þ (9) Split 3:
CVð%Þ ¼ 170:95ð±0:93Þ þ 19:18ð±0:07Þ*DCWð1;10Þ (10) Table 6 contains the statistical characteristics of these models. Fig. 1 shows the graphical representation of quasi-QSAR models calculated with Eqs. (5)e(10). Fig. 1 (a), (b), and (c) are graphs for quasi-QSAR models built with three splits generated by HCA code assignment method. Fig. 1 (d), (e), and (f) are graphs for quasi-QSAR models built with three data splits generated by min-max code assignment method. As shown in Fig. 1, relatively small residuals between prediction and experiment were visually observed from quasi-QSAR models built using HCA code assignment method.
The statistical quality of the models developed using quasiSMILES based on HCA is good in comparison with the other

models built with quasi-SMILES coded by the min-max normalization method as shown in Fig. 2.
Tables S3eS5 provide the correlation weights for codes which are components of quasi-SMILES generated by HCA. Positive
correlation weight increases cell viability, while negative correlation weight decreases cell viability. In particular, negative correlation weights appeared in codes (C8, E8, and E9) related to surface charge and dose. The code ‘C8’ covers a range of surface charge from 16.6 to 24.4mV. It means that the positive surface charge, which is ranged from 16.6 to 24.4mV, reduces the cell viability. The code ‘E8’ and ‘E9’ were assigned to cover the dose range from 1200.1 to 1500.0 mg/mL. It implies that high dose reduces cell viability.
There is a significant difference between the average correlation weights of dose-related Ck (e.g., average CW (E0)z 3.00± 0.12, whereas CW (E9)z 0.47± 0.06). It implies that the influence of dose is most significant.
The applicability of these models can be defined according to a scheme described in the literature (Toropov and Toropova, 2015a, 2015b) using the defects of quasi-SMILES that are calculated on the basis of probabilities that describe the likely presence of different features in the training and calibration set.
In previously published papers (Manganelli et al., 2016a; Manganelli et al., 2016b; Toropova et al., 2015c), cell viability (%) of Human Embryonic Kidney Cells (HEK293) exposed to silica nanomaterials was used as the endpoint of the developed quasi-QSAR models. Experimental datasets on the cytotoxicity of eight nanomaterials were used for predicting the cell viability (%) of BEAS-2B (Toropova and Toropov, 2017). In this study, the cell viability (%) of both BEAS-2B and HaCaT for twenty-one nanomaterials was used
as the endpoint. The performance of the model was significantly improved by applying the HCA method to the numerical descriptors (core size, hydrodynamic size, surface charge, and dose). All possible codes were assigned to 10 subintervals divided by HCA. It led to the performance improvement.
In our previous study using the HCA-based quasi-SMILES (Trinh et al., 2018a) for predicting the cytotoxicity of human lung cells to MWCNTs, the model performance for the validation set, R squared, was average 0.85, while the performance of the model for predicting the cytotoxicity of human lung and skin cells to metal oxide nanomterials was average 0.74. The dose descriptor was identified as the most influential factor for increasing the toxicity of nanomaterials in both studies. For predicting the cytotoxicity of MWCNTs, 276 toxicity data measured at a dose range from 0 to 200 ppmwere used. On the other hand, 336 toxicity data measured at a wider dose range from 0 to 1500 ppmwere used for predicting the cytotoxicity of metal oxide nanomaterials. In both studies, 10 codes were equally used for representing each dose range. The same number of codes were used, but in this study the codes covered a wider dose range. It implies that the quasi-QSAR model for metal oxide nanomaterials is less sensitive to dose change than the quasi-QSAR model for MWCNT. Therefore, the quasi-QSAR model for MWCNTs showed better performance because the model is more sensitive to dose change compared to the model presented in this study. Consequently, this comparison suggests that it needs to consider data range in merging toxicity dataset from different sources and apply quasi-SMILES code assignment method based on HCA to toxicity dataset with no wide data range.
In our study, we generated range codes by means of HCA. For examples, ‘C0’ for dose range from 0 to 35.0 mg/mL, and ‘C1’ for dose range from 35.1 to 68.0 mg/mL. The range codes enable expansion of the applicability domain of the quasi-QSAR models. The toxicity of new input data which is able to be represented by the range codes can be predicted by the proposed models. The majority of existing quasi-QSARmodels were developed using fixed codes (e.g., ‘A’ for 5 mg/mL, ‘B’ for 50 mg/mL). In case of quasi-QSAR models developed using fixed codes, themodels could not predict an endpoint for new input data if a fixed code for the data was not assigned. Because of this, the utilization of existing quasi-QSAR models is limited. Therefore, the HCA-based quasi-SMILES code assignment method could be one of the solutions to overcome the limitation of existing quasi-QSAR models in terms of the practical use of the models.
The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) guidance document for QSAR models recommends that QSAR models should be associated with the following: (i) a defined endpoint, (ii) an unambiguous algorithm; (iii) a defined domain of applicability; (iv) appropriate measures for goodness-of-fit, robustness, and predictivity, and (v) a mechanistic interpretation, if possible (OECD, 2014). The CORAL software addressed in Section Quasi-QSAR modelling is a tool based on Monte Carlo optimisation method to build up QSARs for various endpoints, and its methodology complies with the OECD principles (M Veselinovic et al., 2015; Toropov et al., 2013a; Toropova et al., 2012; Toropova and Toropov, 2014).
The following points show how the developed quasi-QSAR models have compliance with the OECD principles:
(i) A defined endpoint: The cell viability results of the BEAS-2B and HaCaT, expressed as a percentage compared with control samples, were used as toxicity endpoints on inhalation and dermal toxicity, respectively;
(ii) An unambiguous algorithm: The Monte Carlo optimisation which is represented by the CORAL software was used;
(iii) A defined domain of applicability: The applicability domain of the proposed quasi-QSAR models can be defined the detect of quasi-SMILES, a criterion to detect outliers; (iv) Appropriate measures for goodness-of-fit, robustness, and
predictivity: Adjusted R2, Q2, MAE, and c R2p were used for
evaluating the proposed model; and (v) A mechanistic interpretation: The correlation weights were
used. Positive correlation weight increases cell viability, while negative correlation weight decreases cell viability.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this study, quasi-QSAR models were developed to predict the cell viability (%) of BEAS-2B and HaCaT cells exposed to 21 metal oxide nanomaterials. The toxicity dataset whichwas extracted from the S2NANO database and evaluated by PChem scoring approach was used. In particular, HCA and min-max normalization method were respectively used in assigning alphanumeric codes for numerical descriptors. Model performances were improved by means of the quasi-SMILES coding method based on HCA. The quasi-QSAR models were also developed in compliance with the OECD principles for validating QSAR models.
The results of HCA are dependent on the data range. If data with a wide range is used, the important data range contributing to the critical endpoint changes could be involved in the less important data range. Thus, additional studies are required for defining the preferable data size and the number of groups with consideration for the correlation between data of attributes and the endpoint.
Declaration of interest

referenceMentions.context: The toxicity of nanomaterials has been evaluated by conducting in vivo, in vitro, and in silico studies (Frohlich and Salar-Behzadi, 2014).

In particular, in silico studies have been conducted to complement in vitro and in vivo toxicity tests to potentiallyminimize the need for animal testing, reduce the cost and time of toxicity tests, and improve toxicity prediction and safety assessment (Raies and Bajic, 2016).

including the toxicity of various substances (Randi c, 1991), mainly based on molecular structure (McNaught and Wilkinson, 1997), simplified molecular input line entry systems (SMILES) (Weininger, 1988), and international chemical identifiers (InChI) (Heller et al.

) (Gatoo et al., 2014; Podila and Brown, 2013; Zhao et al., 2012), it makes the development of classic QSAR difficult.
) (Gatoo et al., 2014; Podila and Brown, 2013; Zhao et al., 2012), it makes the development of classic QSAR difficult.
) (Gatoo et al., 2014; Podila and Brown, 2013; Zhao et al., 2012), it makes the development of classic QSAR difficult.

To overcome the limitations of classic QSAR on nanomaterials, QSAR based quasi-SMILES (quasi-QSAR) were proposed by Toropova and Toropov (A Toropov et al., 2015; Bragazzi et al., 2016; Manganelli et al., 2016a; Manganelli et al., 2016b; P Toropova and A Toropov, 2015; Toropov et al., 2013b, 2015, 2016; Toropov and Toropova, 2014, 2015b; Toropova and Toropov, 2013, 2017; Toropova et al., 2014, 2015a, 2015b, 2015c, 2016a, 2016b, 2017).

Quasi-SMILES is representation of eclectic data related to an endpoint, where eclectic data is all conditions (controlled or observed) that have influence over the experiment results (Bragazzi et al., 2016).
, character string), all of the available eclectic data that impacts the physicochemical and/or biochemical behavior of nanomaterials (Toropov et al., 2015).
For numerical descriptors such as physicochemical properties, theminmax normalizationmethod was used (Toropova and Toropov, 2013; Toropova et al., 2014).
For numerical descriptors such as physicochemical properties, theminmax normalizationmethod was used (Toropova and Toropov, 2013; Toropova et al., 2014).
The quality of collected toxicity data was assessed by physicochemical (PChem) scoring approach proposed by the S2NANO research group (Ha et al., 2018; Trinh et al., 2018b).
From the S2NANO database, BEAS-2B and HaCaT cells were chosen in this study because they are widely used as models relevant for nanomaterial toxicity evaluations (Gibbs, 2009).

The cell viability data originated from 6 research articles (Akhtar et al., 2012; Comfort et al., 2014; Gajewicz et al., 2015; Xiong et al., 2013; Yang et al., 2010; Zhang et al., 2012) about the cytotoxicity of metal oxide nanomaterials.

The cell viability data originated from 6 research articles (Akhtar et al., 2012; Comfort et al., 2014; Gajewicz et al., 2015; Xiong et al., 2013; Yang et al., 2010; Zhang et al., 2012) about the cytotoxicity of metal oxide nanomaterials.

Having the numerical data on CW(Ck) one can calculate DCW(T, NEpoch) for all quasi-SMILES (for more detailed information see references (Toropov and Toropova, 2014; Toropova and Toropov, 2013; Toropova et al., 2015a)).

Having the numerical data on CW(Ck) one can calculate DCW(T, NEpoch) for all quasi-SMILES (for more detailed information see references (Toropov and Toropova, 2014; Toropova and Toropov, 2013; Toropova et al., 2015a)).
parameter c R(2)p ensures that the developed models are not obtained by chance (Y-randomisation test) (Ojha and Roy, 2011).
Experimental datasets on the cytotoxicity of eight nanomaterials were used for predicting the cell viability (%) of BEAS-2B (Toropova and Toropov, 2017).

The CORAL software addressed in Section Quasi-QSAR modelling is a tool based on Monte Carlo optimisation method to build up QSARs for various endpoints, and its methodology complies with the OECD principles (M Veselinovic et al., 2015; Toropov et al., 2013a; Toropova et al., 2012; Toropova and Toropov, 2014).

The CORAL software addressed in Section Quasi-QSAR modelling is a tool based on Monte Carlo optimisation method to build up QSARs for various endpoints, and its methodology complies with the OECD principles (M Veselinovic et al., 2015; Toropov et al., 2013a; Toropova et al., 2012; Toropova and Toropov, 2014).

metadata.abstractText: A quasi-QSAR model was developed to predict the cell viability of human lung (BEAS-2B) and skin (HaCaT) cells exposed to 21 types of metal oxide nanomaterials. A wide range of toxicity datasets obtained from the S2NANO (www.s2nano.org) database was used. The data of descriptors representing the physicochemical properties and experimental conditions were coded to quasi-SMILES. In particular, hierarchical cluster analysis (HCA) and min-max normalization method were respectively used in assigning alphanumeric codes for numerical descriptors (e.g., core size, hydrodynamic size, surface charge, and dose) and then quasi-QSAR model performances for both methods were compared. The quasi-QSAR models were developed using CORAL software (www.insilico.eu/coral). Quasi-QSAR model built using quasi-SMILES generated by means of HCA showed better performance than the min-max normalization method. The model showed satisfactory statistical results (Radj for the training dataset: 0.71e0.73; Radj for the calibration dataset: 0.74e0.82; and R 2 adj for the validation dataset: 0.70e0.76). © 2018 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
